history.content:
There’s a fair amount of content in 152 not covered in 61C, like out-of-order execution and VLIW.

----

I think it's also important to point out that just because topics like caches or virtual memory aren't "new" to you doesn't mean you can't learn more about them (there are a ton of intricacies and history involved with this field especially). I would say that 61C leaves you with a basic understanding of these concepts, while 152 fills in the gaps and allows you to understand these ideas at a deeper level. I was a 61C TA and I still learned a lot from 152 when I took it. After 61C you can understand the basic ideas and can carry a decent conversation on the subject, but 152 gives you a much more solid understanding (and the exams are quite hard and a different experience from 61c). It's a really good class and I would recommend taking it if you are at all interested in the topics.
There’s a fair amount of content in 152 not covered in 61C, like out-of-order execution and VLIW.

children.subject: + 1 also 152 has real written homework which is IMO better for reinforcing ideas than the online homework 61C had when I took it
also today you learned that 152 is the class full of 61C TAs

I would say 152 assumes a decent grasp of 61C and then goes much, much deeper. As the previous answer mentioned, there are several topics that 61C doesn’t even touch on in the context of superscalar (out of order, VLIW, vector machines). It also explores topics like memory hierarchies and branch prediction (things that might look familiar from 61C) in great detail, using labs as an opportunity to explore them deeply. IMO one of the best possible classes to take if you loved 61C!

history.content: I looked at the course description for CS152 and it looks awfully similar to the things taught in CS61C. I was wondering how much new content do we truly learn in CS152 if we've already taken 61C? Is it one of those classes where there is no truly "new concepts" we are learning but rather we are learning how to design/build the things we previously learned about?
history.subject: CS 152
